reviewText: I was thinking I would watch the movie to kill some time, then my hopes were perked to actually expecting something.  Frack me running!  One of the worst please god tell me there is not a cult following to this flick, because the only ho joke scene was the part about the electric vaginia fighting the electric ovary? Or Fertile Egg??  Other then that, vaguely vieled social message and super cheap special effects.  FFC ought to go hide his head in shame for this one.

reviewText: Mikhail Karzhukov's 1960 "Nebo Zoyvot" or "The Heavens Call" was Cormanized in 1962. The original is an artifact of the "Cold War" and needs to be restored to its original format to be fully appreciated. The original story line -- Russians helping Americans in space -- was later used to good effect in "2010". I give the original film five stars.Corman bought the film cheap while in Europe. Coppolla reworked the Russian script into something supposedly pallatable to the American audience, added some garish monster so they could put it on the poster, reused footage to give it more length and recieved his first screen credit. Heaven forbid someone should do that to his film! But this sort of hacking was not unusual at the time as Corman (and Mystery Science Theater) fans know. Still, this DVD does have a decent transfer of the Corman version.The second half of this double feature is an Italian sci-fi gone wrong. A generous star or so for that one.Again, where's the original Russian film?

reviewText: Battle Beyond the Sun:  The Russian film "Nebo Zovyot" was brought to America and re-edited into an Americanized dubbed version.  It would be interesting to see the original film.  Audio/Video is good with only minor imperfections.  Star Pilot:  A dubbed and re-edited Italian film("2+5:  Missione Hydra").  The color in this film has a problem with color fluctuations throughout the film.  Otherwise, the audio/video is OK and the dubbing is typical.  In both films, and especially in Star Pilot, the re-editing and missing footage can be rather obvious.  Both films are in full-screen.
